comments.body: @goderbauer do you remember why we even support suppressing output?

It looks like it's because the bash code whence this was forked redirected stdout to `/dev/null`.  That in turn was originated in https://github.com/flutter/flutter/pull/3977.

I'm gonna send a PR to remove it.  Swallowing the stdio obfuscated a serious Windows issue last night.
Sounds good.
Sent https://github.com/flutter/flutter/pull/16666
was this intentional?

Yes - to help see what tests were running on the bots. Here's the before: https://travis-ci.org/flutter/flutter/jobs/223314813#L5740, and the after: https://travis-ci.org/flutter/flutter/jobs/223317672#L5804.

```
a.length == b.length && a.asMap().keys.every((int i) => a[i] == b[i])
```
How strongly do you feel about this? I think the code I have now is both more efficient and more readable, but I don't feel strongly about this.
I like the brevity, but I don't feel strongly about it, so your call.
I think you can just make this take `File file` since you have the `entity is File` check above

[error] The function expression type '(File) â†’ Set<String>' isn't of type '(FileSystemEntity) â†’ Set<String>'. This means its parameter or return type does not match what is expected. Consider changing parameter type(s) or the returned type(s).
This is great!

This seems to assume that the last 'RUNNING' message will inform the reader about the error.  I don't think you can assume that's true, since the processes run asynchronously. If that's correct, then it would be best to repeat the relativeWorkingDir, commandDescription (and the environment) on failure. It's probably worthwhile always printing this stuff anyway, since there might be tons of program output above the error message.
Done.
how about these?
Not sure how `pub run` can run in dart2 mode.

We need to file an issue against pub for this.
Currently it has the following options for pub run
Usage: pub run <executable> [args...]
-h, --help            Print this usage information.
-c, --[no-]checked    Enable runtime type checks and assertions.
    --mode            Mode to run transformers in.
                      (defaults to "release" for dependencies, "debug" for entrypoint)

it needs another option here '--preview-dart-2' to be consistent that would run in dart2 mode.
Opened https://github.com/dart-lang/sdk/issues/32214
Why not put this in `flutter_tools/test/forbidden_imports_test.dart`?
Ah, because it applies to more than flutter_tools ðŸ˜„
That only checks `flutter_tools`. This checks the whole repo.
We don't have to worry about the Windows "access denied" error here?
I don't think we run analysis on Windows.
Is there a performance impact to this? If no, It should be ok to run all tests with that flag just to get more coverage.
Running the tests with the flag takes only slightly longer than running the tests without the flag.
OK, let's se what the impact is and if it gets too slow we can always revisit.

https://github.com/flutter/flutter/wiki/Style-guide-for-Flutter-repo#never-check-if-a-port-is-available-before-using-it-never-add-timeouts-and-other-race-conditions

(and several places below)
This was existing code from this test.  I'm not entirely sure why it's there or if it's really necessary.
https://github.com/flutter/flutter/wiki/Style-guide-for-Flutter-repo#avoid-checking-in-comments-that-ask-questions
nit: stray comment on this line?
It seems like we might be able to use the same logic as what I'm attempting in https://github.com/flutter/flutter/pull/34877
I'm not quite sure - the coverage collection uses a test runner that I wrote, since it isn't supported by package:test or build_runner
Ahh ok.
Putting these all in `gradle1` makes that test take almost 40 minutes.  Can we split them out?
Good point. I'd like to try parallelize these calls. Do you know how many cores each VM on  cirrus have?
Can we just put all these stuff into subshard 3?
Also could you remove the expectIpaBuildFailure parameter in _flutterBuildIpa since now it's unused?
Done.
We need to update the logic at https://github.com/flutter/flutter/pull/35839/files#diff-a9d73960c607f511d218217af489e4d5R587 and following for this
Not quite sure what you mean
There's logic in there to check the subshard and run the right subset of tests using tags.  I don't think it matches the logic in the build runner variant of the method.
Oh duh, got it my bad
Is there an issue filed for this? If so it should go in the TODO comment somewhere.
It's https://github.com/flutter/flutter/issues/39991
Is there an issue filed for this TODO?
It's https://github.com/flutter/flutter/issues/37525.  https://github.com/flutter/flutter/issues/37519 is a really good idea.
Does this guarantee that `end <= allTests.length`? IOW is there a risk of getting a `RangeError`?
yes because we don't do the last shard here, we do it below.
Ah, gotcha!
Should `_runFlutterTest()` always just do a pass with `--track-widget-creation` and a pass with `--no-track-widget-creation`?
that could get pretty expensive. What bugs are you hoping to catch?
I was just reacting to the fact that we seem to be calling it with both of those flags in many places already.
some places, yeah. intentionally not all though.
If we ever add a new directory that matches `packages/flutter/test/**/widgets`, its tests will silently never be run...
unless i misunderstand, i don't believe that's an issue; `recursive` is false
Ah, I missed the recursive:false - nevermind.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +377,381 @@      .listSync(followLinks: false, recursive: false)
      .whereType<Directory>()
      .where((Directory dir) => dir.path.endsWith('widgets') == false)
      .map<String>((Directory dir) => path.join('test', path.basename(dir.path)) + path.separator)
      .toList();

comments.body: Can you make sure that this cleanup will yield Cirrus tests that pass on dev, beta, and stable?  Right now, we have tests that are guaranteed to fail on those channels (e.g. because Flutter for web is disabled on non-master).
I'm not sure how to test that short of actually doing a release.

You could temporarily (with no intention of submitting) edit the tools logic for what channel you're on to synthesize fake runs of dev|beta|stable.  I leave it up to you on whether that churn of git push, wait, repeat is worth it.
Why shuffle it at all if we're going to hard code the seed?
I'm not sure what Ian's motivation was, but I like this change because randomizing should break up clusters of big tests making sharding more effective.
Might be worth a comment explaining why this is done.

yeah you want to shuffle so that the average cost-per-file is uniform.
i'll add a comment.
It looks like we can probably remove `key` now (it looks like we never set `$SHARD` or `$SUBSHARD` anymore).
I'll add a comment. It's useful when doing local testing so you can run a whole shard (or a specific shard+subshard) without having to figure out the corresponding task name.
You can say `recursive: true` and not need the `existsSync()` check
Interesting. Done.

Looks like you were wrong. :-)
https://cirrus-ci.com/task/6550651382792192?command=main#L104
It happens to the best of us.  I even wrote a [test that shows what the behavior is](https://github.com/google/file.dart/blob/master/packages/file/test/common_tests.dart#L2735) ðŸ˜„
I wish enums could have properties & methods like they can in Java.

cc @tvolkert @blasten this block is new, it's the result of merging with @blasten's recent changes

Basically I took the same approach as with the web tests (though sadly it's different enough that I couldn't reuse code).
I would start with the assumption that this is running in a separate shard.
Done
Is the TODO above this now on the wrong line?

Could you test it without --fast-start?

Could you add a comment explaining the reason to skip it?
Added a comment explaining the skip: there is nothing to build for this app
